items.title: event loop threading issue
items.body:
When txaio is used in
 * an asyncio context (so `_AsyncioApi` is in use)
 * a multithreading environment, with multiple event loops in each thread

there is issues with working in the correct event loop.

Current code uses the event loop which can either be globally configured or the one from the thread which imports txaio the first time and this loop is used for the rest of the runtime of the program. First is no option if multiple loops/threads are in action, and second happens that way because the `_AsyncioApi` object is initialized at import time of `aio.py` and at `_AsyncioApi.__init__` the event loop is set to `config.loop`, in case `config.loop` is None, which is active in the current thread, or if in mainthread, it is created (in a non- mainthread, with no current event loop yet, this would btw result in a RuntimeError).

Applied patch/PR fixes this.

items.title: Drop support for Python < 3.5
items.body: pls see the respective AB issue: https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/issues/1282

items.title: Support import time framework selection
items.body:
Currently to use txaio we have to either call `use_twisted()` or `use_asyncio()` at the start of a python file, while it works great, it doesn't look good. flake8 doesn't like that as well since we add more imports after the `use_twisted()` call.

It would be good if the library had a way to select the framework on import, something along the lines
```
from txaio import with_twisted as txaio
```

items.title: support 'synchronous' code with a fake loop
items.body:
add support for a mode where every Future completes synchronously.

This way someone could write an adapter that can use one of twisted.web, requests or aiohttp and still get back a future.

Client library code would use this adapter as if it were twisted.web, except if you used requests the library could provide results synchronously by querying a special property on the txaio Future.

items.title: Mention we support Py 3.6 in README
items.body: Platform support in the README needs to mention Python 3.6 support

items.title: Python3 and Twisted
items.body:
Twisted now supports the Python3-style `async def` functions. This is via a new API called `ensureDeferred`.

However, the `tx` side of txaio only uses `maybeDeferred` in `txaio.as_future` and `maybeDeferred` does not support `async def`. So, we should add some logic and tests to `txaio.tx.as_future` so that it (maybe) calls `ensureDeferred` in the correct circumstances.

Either that or convince Twisted that `maybeDeferred` should do this. Or maybe we *just* need to call `ensureDeferred` for all cases?

items.title: txaio should use loop.create_future() and loop.create_task() instead of asyncio.Future() and asyncio.Task()
items.body:
This allows the used loop implementation to its own version of the two objects, maybe with customizations/speedups. It's also the preferred way of creating such objects since 3.5.2. See 
https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html?highlight=create_future#asyncio.AbstractEventLoop.create_future

items.body: Moving this here from https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/issues/827 since it's really a txaio issue.

items.title: Issue when running with Crossbar 17.3.1 and Python 3.6.1
items.body:
Trying the latest CB release, my test suite raises the following exception:
```
ERROR:root:While firing onDisconnect: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/txaio/aio.py", line 389, in done
    f._result = x
AttributeError: attribute '_result' of '_asyncio.Future' objects is not writable
```

I think this is caused by the fact that starting with Python 3.6.1 `asyncio.Future` is written in C, and thus it's not anymore possible to alter/create new arbitrary attributes.

items.title: Test failing on Python 3.6
items.body:
One test is failing on Python 3.6: `test_chained_callback` Tested on `Python 3.6.0rc`

```
________________________________________________________________________ test_chained_callback[asyncio] ________________________________________________________________________

framework = <module 'txaio.aio' from '/txaio/txaio/aio.py'>

    def test_chained_callback(framework):
        """
        Chain two callbacks where the first one alters the value.
        """
        calls = []
    
        def callback0(arg):
            print('callback 0', arg)
            calls.append(arg)
            return arg + " pray I do not alter it futher"
    
        def callback1(arg):
            print('callback 1', arg)
            calls.append(arg)
    
        f = txaio.create_future()
        txaio.add_callbacks(f, callback0, None)
        txaio.add_callbacks(f, callback1, None)
        txaio.resolve(f, "the deal")
    
        run_once()
    
        assert len(calls) == 2
        assert calls[0] == "the deal"
>       assert calls[1] == "the deal pray I do not alter it futher"
E       assert 'the deal' == 'the deal pray I do not alter it futher'
E         - the deal
E         + the deal pray I do not alter it futher

test/test_callback.py:86: AssertionError
```

items.title: txaio-2.5.1 fails tests at the distro level
items.body:
The test/test_packaging.py file should not be included as part of the normal release tarballs.
On Gentoo I have had to rm the file to prevent test failures as part of the install process when FEATURES=test is enabled.  This test is obviously for developing the code only.   Not for testing the code itself.  The failure was due to the sandbox and multiple python install/test capabilities in Gentoo.  I did not delve deeply into the failure, but it was obviously a path issue due to the sandbox.

All other tests passed once I removed that test.

items.title: txaio std lib logging
items.body:
Please see https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_source=digest&utm_medium=email#!topic/autobahnws/vxb4e03IUOQ

``` python
# Name would allow for _TxaioLogWrapper to not call std lib logging.getLogger with no name thus defaulting to root logging instance 
def make_logger(name=None):
    logger = _TxaioLogWrapper(logging.getLogger(name))
    # remember this so we can set their levels properly once
    # start_logging is actually called
    _loggers.add(logger)
    return logger


def start_logging(name=None, out=_stdout, level='info'):
    """
    Begin logging.

    :param out: if provided, a file-like object to log to. By default, this is
                stdout.
    :param level: the maximum log-level to emit (a string)
    """
    global _log_level, _loggers, _started_logging     ****** I tried setting log level to "none" and that passes this test but isn't implemented and throws another error
    if level not in log_levels:
        raise RuntimeError(
            "Invalid log level '{0}'; valid are: {1}".format(
                level, ', '.join(log_levels)
            )
        )

    if _started_logging:
        return

    _started_logging = True
    _log_level = level

    handler = _TxaioFileHandler(out)
    logging.getLogger(name).addHandler(handler)   ****** Name here too so that root logger isn't used
    # note: Don't need to call basicConfig() or similar, because we've
    # now added at least one handler to the root logger
    logging.raiseExceptions = True  # FIXME
    level_to_stdlib = {
        'critical': logging.CRITICAL,
        'error': logging.ERROR,
        'warn': logging.WARNING,
        'info': logging.INFO,
        'debug': logging.DEBUG,
        'trace': logging.DEBUG,
    }
    logging.getLogger(name).setLevel(level_to_stdlib[level])   ****** Name here too so that root logger isn't used
    # make sure any loggers we created before now have their log-level
    # set (any created after now will get it from _log_level
    for logger in _loggers:
        logger._set_log_level(level)
```

Maybe even better we could pass a std lib logging instance into make_logger, in case we are already using the root logger instance?

items.title: support for @inlineCallbacks
items.body:
Would it be possible to support inlineCallbacks?
I would like to do something similar to the code below:

``` python
from __future__ import print_function
import txaio
from asyncio.futures import Future
from asyncio.coroutines import coroutine
import asyncio
txaio.use_asyncio()
from twisted.internet.defer import Deferred
from twisted.internet.defer import inlineCallbacks
from twisted.internet import reactor


@inlineCallbacks
def test1():
    dfd = Deferred()
    reactor.callLater(1, dfd.callback, 'Test1 OK')
    print('Test1 started')
    res = yield dfd
    print(res)


@inlineCallbacks
def test2():
    fut = Future()
    reactor.callLater(1, fut.set_result, 'Test1 OK')
    print('Test2 started')
    res = yield fut
    print(res)

@coroutine
def test3():
    fut = Future()
    reactor.callLater(1, fut.set_result, 'Test1 OK')
    print('Test3 started')
    res = yield fut
    print(res)

test1()
test2()
test3()

asyncio.get_event_loop().run_forever()
```

results when I used the asyncio eventloop

```
Test1 started
Test2 started
<Future pending>
```

results when using `reactor.run()`

```
Test1 started
Test2 started
<Future pending>
Test1 OK
```

items.title: Logging changes in 55ca3e40ab create problems with older code, e.g. autobahn-python
items.body:
Crux of the issue seem to be that e.g. autobahn-python does things like these:

```
self.log.debug("received HTTP headers in opening handshake : %s" % str(self.http_headers))
```

And new logging api (introduced in 55ca3e40ab, according to git-blame) does not support that, as it then calls `str.format()` on the passed string, which should never be called on essentially random string like one produced by the line above.

Link to that line in current autobahn-python: https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/blob/c6ca54d794/autobahn/websocket/protocol.py#L2327

Submitted issue here, as fixing logging calls in autobahn should leave-out anyone with older autobahn and newer txaio, so thought that maybe it's possible to have fix here, making old logging calls compatible with new api instead?

A bit more details follow.

---

So, when using WAMP in autobahn-python with Python-3.5/asyncio, I'm seeing this:

```
2016-04-04 20:39:12 :: asyncio ERROR: Exception in callback WebSocketAdapterProtocol._consume.<locals>.process(<Future finished result=None>) at /home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/asyncio/websocket.py:105
handle: <Handle WebSocketAdapterProtocol._consume.<locals>.process(<Future finished result=None>) at /home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/asyncio/websocket.py:105>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/asyncio/events.py", line 125, in _run
    self._callback(*self._args)
  File "/home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/asyncio/websocket.py", line 109, in process
    self._dataReceived(data)
  File "/home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/websocket/protocol.py", line 1176, in _dataReceived
    self.consumeData()
  File "/home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/websocket/protocol.py", line 1205, in consumeData
    self.processHandshake()
  File "/home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/websocket/protocol.py", line 3484, in processHandshake
    self.log.debug("received HTTP headers in opening handshake : %s" % str(self.http_headers))
  File "/home/fraggod/.py3/txaio/aio.py", line 109, in _log
    msg = log_format.format(**kwargs)
KeyError: "'sec-websocket-protocol'"
2016-04-04T20:39:12 Exception in callback WebSocketAdapterProtocol._consume.<locals>.process(<Future finished result=None>) at /home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/asyncio/websocket.py:105
handle: <Handle WebSocketAdapterProtocol._consume.<locals>.process(<Future finished result=None>) at /home/fraggod/.py3/autobahn/asyncio/websocket.py:105>
```

Looking into txaio.aio, issue seem to be that `msg = log_format.format(**kwargs)` is with "log_format" already having templated-in data - in this case headers dict - and hence looks like this:

```
received HTTP headers in opening handshake : {'sec-websocket-protocol': 'wamp.2.json.batched', ...
```

And then running pretty much any `str.format()` on that would inevitably produce error above, due to `{}` things in there.

items.title: as_future and generators
items.body:
Both twisted and asyncio come with decorators which allow to write async code as if synchronous (`@inlineCallbacks` and `@coroutine` for reference). However it's easy to forget these decorators either while writing code or while refactoring code (e.g switching from a synchronous implementation of a func to async).

I argue that in 90% of all cases where a function returning a generator is passed into `as_future` the user actually just forgot the decorator. This can lead to nasty and hard to debug behaviour. E.g Autobahn's `ApplicationSession.onJoin` handler will simply not be invoked at all, but at the same time there isn't any feedback about this as well. The application will just continue as usual although code which was intended to be executed, was not. Due to the dynamic nature of Python, this can mean that actual errors might happen much much later. Cause and effect might not be that obvious to identify due to them being seperated by a very long period of time.

I propose that returning a generator from a function which is passed into `as_future` is to be considered an error. For the case that one actually wants to return a generator, the function should be decorated with `@txaio.returns_gen` which will wrap the generator in a `_Generator` marker object telling the `as_future` implementation, that returning a generator was actually intented.

I'm aware of the fact that this is not consistent in behaviour with e.g `maybeDeferred` but I believe this the right place to implement that check. Otherwise it would mean that every piece of code which would need such a check would have to do it on its own which is just as easy to forget. Also this adds alot of boilerplate everytime.

items.title: Tie into default logging if start_logging() is never called
items.body:
See https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/issues/596

We _should_ be able to tie into Python's internal logging system properly even in the case when `txaio.start_logging()` isn't ever called.

items.title: JSON color logging
items.body:
Not sure what's exactly the best approach implementation-wise, but the code here

https://github.com/crossbario/crossbar/blob/master/crossbar/common/checkconfig.py#L138

would be useful in app components (colorful logging) too!

That is, a class deriving from ApplicationSession might use the colored logging like eg here

https://github.com/crossbario/crossbarexamples/blob/master/authentication/ticket/dynamic/authenticator.py#L69

items.title: First parameter for txaio.aio._log should be named differently
items.body:
Autobahn currently has a bug due to it calling `self.log.error(..., msg=...)` as "msg" is the name of the first argument to _log(), leading to an exception:

```
TypeError: _log() got multiple values for argument 'msg'
```

The relevant code in autobahn is [here](https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/blob/master/autobahn/wamp/protocol.py#L387-L391).

items.title: Importing txaio messes up logging when using trollius
items.body:
It starts spitting messages like 
`<LogRecord: trollius, 10, .../lib/python2.7/site-packages/trollius/selector_events.py, 72, "Using selector: %s">`

Why do you call `logging.getLogger("trollius").addHandler(PrintHandler())` without asking the user, anyway? Not to mention that your `PrintHandler` is completely broken.

items.title: Complain if you explicitly set the "other" framework
items.body:
Currently, if you call `.use_twisted()` and then later call `.use_asyncio()` txaio will merrily swap out for the asyncio methods.

It should be an error if you explicitly call `.use_twisted()` and `.use_asyncio()` in the same process (but not, e.g., if Twisted was auto-selected but you call .use_asyncio() explicitly nor if you call .use_asyncio() > 1 time).

See also https://github.com/crossbario/autobahn-python/issues/547

items.title: Error in loading autobahn/txaio
items.body:
I have a project that requires autobahn in its setup.py. The project is [pymata-aio](https://github.com/MrYsLab/pymata-aio).

The actual project that the user is trying to pip  load is [s2aio](https://github.com/MrYsLab/s2aio), which requires pymata-aio and in turn, requires autobahn/txaio.

Both pymata-aio and s2aio are available on pypi.

The require statement I am using for pymata-aio is:
`
install_requires=['pyserial>=2.7', 'autobahn[asyncio]>=0.10.4'],
`

Both projects require the use of Python 3.5

I have a user who is trying to load on Windows 7  32 bit and is getting this error:

```
Collecting txaio>=1.1.0 (from autobahn[asyncio]>=0.10.4->pymata-aio>=2.7->s2aio)

  Downloading txaio-2.0.4.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 20, in <module>
      File "C:\temp\pip-build-nbvbbr9i\txaio\setup.py", line 40, in <module>
        with open('README.rst') as f:
    OSError: [Errno 22] Invalid argument: 'README.rst'

    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in C:\temp\pip-build-nbvbbr9i\txaio
```

I am able to load on Windows 10 64 bit and do not see this error. 

Any thoughts on what might be going on and how to resolve this?

Thanks

items.title: Usages of asyncio objects (Future, Task, etc), must be provided with the loop kwarg
items.body: txio takes an event loop for configuration txaio.config.loop.  Unfortunately, this is only used in the aio.call_later() function.  It should also be used in all asyncio calls (Future, Task, gather, etc).

items.body:

Tag 2.02
Windows 10
Python 3.5.0

Work around: installing from source works fine, which makes it non-obvious how to fix this.

Problem:

Collecting txaio

items.title: is_future helper?
items.body:
Hi,

I’m trying to write decorators that can handle coroutines and would like to write something like this generally:

``` python
self.__enter__()
rv = f(*a, **kw)
if asyncio.iscoroutine(rv):
    rv = asyncio.ensure_future(rv)
    rv.add_done_callback(lambda _: self.__exit__(None, None, None))
else:
    self.__exit__(None, None, None)
return rv
```

(i.e. `iscoroutine(rv) or isinstance(rv, Deferred)`)
Briefly scrolling through txaio’s API docs didn’t uncover anything that could help me but maybe I’ve overseen something?  In any case I’d prefer to not implement it myself (also because of async/ensure_future diasphora etc). :)

P.S. See https://github.com/prometheus/client_python/issues/48 for context.

items.title: Polish docs
items.body:
I've setup a GH hook that fires off RTD : http://txaio.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

We should go over the docs and add missing information, improve style and in particular cover what exactly is considered public, long-term stable API and what not.

items.body: For some reason, coverage reports aren't generated from Travis ..

items.title: No version attribute in module
items.body: `txaio.version` is not there.

items.title: Clean up Failure handling
items.body:
In order to be more future-proof and clean up the IFailuedFuture interface we will:
- get rid of everything except `.value` from the interface
- provide `txaio.failure_message(failure)` which returns a unicode
- provide `txaio.failure_traceback(failure)` which returns a traceback object

items.title: New logging
items.body: A logging shim for Twisted and asyncio logging facilities that allows us to write single-source logging code in AutobahnPython

items.title: asyncio imports need SyntaxError
items.body:
See https://github.com/tavendo/AutobahnPython/issues/434

If you have Python 2.7.8 and trollius installed, the `import asyncio` in txaio which is guarded by `except ImportError` will actually throw a `SyntaxError` also/instead. (Tried with Python 2.7.8 on Debian)

items.title: tarball missing util.py
items.body:
The tarball uploaded to pypi is missing the file 
https://github.com/tavendo/txaio/blob/master/test/util.py
rendering the testsuite unusable. Please add. 
Minor tip form #python.  Try inhouse use of
https://github.com/mgedmin/check-manifest/
to assist in picking up lost or missed files. I have never done an uploading process to pypi myself.
